channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: Israel-Hamas War: Israel Expands Daily Combat Pauses to Let Civilians Flee, White House Says
item.description: Israeli authorities, for their part, seemed intent on making clear that the pauses were limited in time and area, not a broader, sustained halt. Israeli soldiers have advanced deep into northern Gaza.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Yousef Masoud for The New York Times
item.media:description: Palestinians mourning family members killed in an airstrike in Khan Younis, Gaza, on Wednesday.

item.title: In Mexico, Surveillance Orders That Read Like a Political Power List
item.description: The Mexico City attorney general’s office ordered the phone records of politicians and officials, court filings show. Many of the people targeted say they were singled out for political reasons.
item.dc:creator: Maria Abi-Habib, Natalie Kitroeff and Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
item.media:credit: Alejandro Cegarra for The New York Times
item.media:description: Under the tenure of President Andrés Manuel López Obrador of Mexico, the country’s military has repeatedly spied on journalists, human rights advocates and even senior members of his own administration.

item.title: This Is What the War in Gaza Looks Like on Instagram
item.description: Trapped in the enclave, Palestinians on the social media platform are documenting and sharing their harrowing experiences of life under Israeli airstrikes and a ground invasion.
item.dc:creator: Yousur Al-Hlou and Nikolay Nikolov

item.title: Germany Remembers Kristallnacht at a Fraught Moment
item.description: As reports of antisemitism surge in Germany and elsewhere, commemorations of the Nazi pogrom have taken on special resonance this year.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze and Graham Bowley
item.media:description: The slogan “Never again is now” was projected onto the Brandenburg Gate in Berlin, marking the 85th anniversary of Kristallnacht.

item.title: The Artistry of Nashenas Speaks to the Afghanistan He Had to Leave Behind
item.description: For his fellow exiles, Sadiq Fitrat Nashenas, an 88-year-old star from a golden era, evokes the Afghanistan they left behind, and one that could have been.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal and Jim Huylebroek
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nashenas at an assistant’s home in Huizen, The Netherlands, last month.

item.title: Vatican Says Transgender People Can Be Baptized and Become Godparents
item.description: A document approved by Pope Francis lays out nuanced guidance in keeping with his vision of a more inclusive church, but it does not amount to a policy change in the church, the Vatican says.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz, Elisabetta Povoledo and Ruth Graham
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.media:description: In his 10-year papacy, Pope Francis has sought to make the Roman Catholic Church more welcoming to L.G.B.T.Q. people, though he opposes same-sex marriage.

item.title: Israel Accuses Freelance Photographers of Advance Knowledge of Oct. 7 Attack
item.description: The New York Times said there was “no evidence” to support such claims about its freelancer.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: A photograph taken by Yousef Masoud for The Associated Press on Oct. 7 shows a breach in the security fence between Gaza and Israel and a disabled Israeli tank. The image was taken more than 90 minutes after the attack began.

item.title: U.K. Home Secretary’s Article in Times of London Stirs Political Storm
item.description: The future of Suella Braverman hung in the balance after she wrote an incendiary opinion article. Downing Street said the piece was unauthorized.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Suella Braverman, Britain’s home secretary, outside 10 Downing Street in London last month.

item.title: Sánchez’s Deal With Catalonia Separatists Creates Turmoil in Spain
item.description: Prime Minister Pedro Sánchez’s agreement with Catalan separatists will likely keep him in power, but it has provoked an upheaval.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:description: People protesting in Madrid near Spain’s Socialist party headquarters this week over negotiations to grant amnesty to people involved with Catalonia’s failed 2017 independence bid.

item.title: Italy Misses a #MeToo Moment in Prime Minister Meloni’s Breakup
item.description: Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni dumped her partner after leaks about come-ons to colleagues. But workplace harassment is still being taken for granted.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:description: Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni and Andrea Giambruno arriving at the Vatican in January for a papal audience.

item.title: Russia Tries to Lure Wagner Veterans Back Into Ukraine War
item.description: A force led by President Vladimir Putin’s former bodyguard is trying to recruit veterans of the paramilitary force, which mutinied against Russian military leaders and saw its leader killed in a plane crash.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev, Ekaterina Bodyagina and Alina Lobzina
item.media:description: Fighters of Wagner private mercenary group outside the headquarters of the Southern Military District base, in Rostov-on-Don, Russia in June.

item.title: Luis Díaz’s Kidnapped Father Is Freed in Colombia
item.description: Luis Manuel Díaz was abducted 12 days ago by a guerrilla group called the National Liberation Army.
item.dc:creator: James Wagner
item.media:credit: Esteban Vanegas/United Nations Mission in Colombia
item.media:description: Luis Manuel Díaz after being freed by National Liberation Army guerrillas on Thursday.

item.title: Palestinian Authority Open to Gaza Role if U.S. Backs 2-State Solution
item.description: The organization, which oversees the West Bank, says it will consider helping run Gaza after the war — if Washington pushes for the creation of a Palestinian state alongside the Israeli one.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: Displaced people from Gaza City relocating to the south of Gaza Strip on Wednesday.

item.title: Can the U.S. Handle China While Supporting Israel and Ukraine Wars?
item.description: To U.S. allies in Asia, the sudden focus on Gaza risks progress on America’s long-delayed pivot to the Indo-Pacific region.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:description: A Chinese Coast Guard ship and a Chinese militia vessel blocking a Philippine Coast Guard ship last month.

item.title: Crocodile Bites Man. Man Bites Back.
item.description: A surprising tale of Northern Territory chutzpah.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: A saltwater crocodile caught in the Northern Territory, at Sydney Wildlife World in Sydney, Australia.

item.title: Omegle Shuts Down as Founder Acknowledges Crime on Video Chat Site
item.description: Omegle’s popularity surged during the pandemic. But critics said that it let online sexual predators go unchecked.
item.dc:creator: Eduardo Medina

item.title: Friday Briefing: Israel Expands Pauses in Combat
item.description: Plus, Hollywood is coming back to life.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: Fleeing toward the southern Gaza on Wednesday.

item.title: Israeli Forces Have Limited Time in Gaza, U.S. Officials Say
item.description: Israel’s response to the Hamas attacks has fueled sympathy around the world for the Palestinian cause even as Israel continues to bury its dead.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper, Eric Schmitt and Adam Goldman
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israel launched a ground invasion in Gaza after the Oct. 7 attack by Hamas and Palestinian Islamic Jihad fighters in southern Israel.

item.title: International Olympic Committee Says It Was Target of Elaborate ‘Fake News’
item.description: Olympic officials said the effort included fabricated quotes about the Israel-Gaza war and a four-part, Netflix-style documentary.
item.dc:creator: Tariq Panja
item.media:description: The Olympic rings in Paris, the site of next year’s Summer Games.

item.title: What Does ‘From the River to the Sea’ Mean?
item.description: The pro-Palestinian rallying cry has become a fixture of protests in the United States and was a focus of the congressional censure of Representative Rashida Tlaib. It has a fraught history.
item.dc:creator: Karoun Demirjian and Liam Stack
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Rashida Tlaib, Democrat of Michigan, was censured by House lawmakers after she used the pro-Palestinian slogan “from the river to the sea.”

item.title: Grass and Shrub Fires More Destructive Than Forest Fires in U.S.
item.description: Grassland and shrubland fires burn more land and destroy more homes across the United States than forest fires, a new study found.
item.dc:creator: Nadja Popovich
item.media:description: Firefighters battled a grass fire in March 2022 in Boulder, Colo.

item.title: Blue Lagoon in Iceland Temporarily Closes After Thousands of Earthquakes
item.description: The tourist attraction, a geothermal spa that is popular with Americans, said it would “carefully monitor the seismic developments” as a precautionary measure.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: “Blue Lagoon has proactively chosen to temporarily suspend operations for one week, despite the authorities not raising the current level of uncertainty during this period of seismic activity,” the Blue Lagoon said in a statement.

item.title: Greenland’s Glaciers Are Melting Faster
item.description: Some glaciers on the island are melting at double the rate of just a few decades ago.
item.dc:creator: Delger Erdenesanaa

item.title: A Bundle of 18th-Century Love Letters Is Unsealed at Last
item.description: More than 100 letters, addressed to French sailors, were never delivered. They remained unopened for nearly 250 years, until a historian found them in Britain’s archives.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:description: Letters to sailors on France’s Galatée warship, which was captured by the British in 1758.

item.title: Archaeologists Look for Traces of Missing in Ashes of Hamas Oct. 7 Attack
item.description: A team of about 15 have recovered the remains of at least 60 people so far, most of them from an Israeli village that suffered devastating losses.
item.dc:creator: Natan Odenheimer
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mourners gathered at the funeral of Lili and Ram Itamari, who were killed in Kfar Aza by Hamas gunmen on Oct. 7.

item.title: Titanic Dinner Menu Is Up for Auction in England This Weekend
item.description: The menu, dated April 11, 1912, is part of a larger sale of maritime items taking place this weekend in England.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:description: A first-class dinner menu from April 11, 1912, the day the Titanic left Queenstown, Ireland, for New York.

item.title: Heirloom Opens First U.S. Direct Air Capture Plant
item.description: The technique is expensive but it could help fight climate change. Backers hope fast growth can bring down costs.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer
item.media:description: A carbon capture plant in Tracy, Calif.

item.title: Holocaust Survivors Faced a Fresh Horror When Hamas Attacked
item.description: At least one Holocaust survivor was killed during the Oct. 7 attack. Others pressed against safe room doors to keep assailants out. One saw a video of her grandson’s abduction.
item.dc:creator: Nadav Gavrielov
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Volunteers with the ZAKA relief organization cleaning a home that was heavily damaged in Kibbutz Holit, where Moshe Ridler, a Holocaust survivor, was killed on Oct. 7.

item.title: Thursday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Yousef Masoud for The New York Times
item.media:description: Palestinians inspecting the damage on Khaled bin Al Waleed mosque in Khan Younis refugee camp on Wednesday.

item.title: How the Rollettes Dance Team Created a Sisterhood for Women with Disabilities
item.description: How Chelsie Hill, the founder of the Rollettes dance team in Los Angeles, created a sisterhood for women and girls with disabilities.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Brinkhurst-Cuff
item.media:credit: Magdalena Wosinska for The New York Times
item.media:description: Chelsie Hill, who was 17 when she was left with spinal injuries after a car accident, founded the Rollettes, a dance team for women who use wheelchairs. Its mission includes mentorship and education.

item.title: Houthi Rebels Shot Down a U.S. Drone Off Yemen’s Coast, Pentagon Says
item.description: The downing of a Reaper drone, the mainstay of the American military’s aerial surveillance fleet, was the latest escalation of violence between the U.S. and Iran-backed groups in Yemen, Iraq and Syria.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: An American MQ-9 Reaper drone in Catania, Italy, last year. Iran-backed Houthi rebels shot down this type of drone off the coast of Yemen on Wednesday, the Pentagon said.

item.title: Blinken Says Palestinian Authority Could Lead Gaza After War
item.description: The secretary of state said Gaza should be overseen by the Palestinian Authority, which has a tenuous hold on power in the Israeli-occupied West Bank.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:description: “We must also work on the affirmative elements to get to a sustained peace,” Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said.

item.title: The White House Condemns Rashida Tlaib’s Embrace of the Phrase ‘River to the Sea’
item.description: The term is widely regarded as a rallying cry for the eradication of Israel, but the congresswoman says it was used as “an aspirational call” for freedom and peace.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Rashida Tlaib of Michigan, center, during a vigil commemorating one month since the Hamas terror attack on Israel, outside the House of Representatives on Tuesday.

item.title: U.S. Strikes Iran-Linked Facility in Syria in Round of Retaliation
item.description: Drone and rocket attacks on U.S. forces have continued in recent weeks, prompting a second round of retaliatory airstrikes in eastern Syria.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt and Helene Cooper
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Air Force F-15E jets carried out the strikes.

item.title: Tens of Thousands Evacuate Northern Gaza as Israel’s Invasion Advances
item.description: The United Nations estimated that 15,000 civilians walked out of northern Gaza on Tuesday, three times as many as the day before, while Israeli troops battled Hamas in Gaza City.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gazans displaced from the North walking along Salah al-Din Road on Wednesday.

item.title: Ukraine Accuses Russia of Deadly Strike on Civilian Ship in Black Sea
item.description: The episode, which killed one and injured four others, comes amid a recent uptick in military activity and attacks in the Black Sea, a hot spot in the war between Russia and Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: A photo released by the Ukrainian authorities showed a damaged civilian ship flying the Liberian flag that Ukraine said had been hit by a Russian missile in the Black Sea region of Odesa.

item.title: Thursday Briefing: What’s Next in the Israel-Hamas War
item.description: Plus, a cook’s tour of the Tokyo food scene.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe
item.media:credit: Yousef Masoud for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israel’s bombardment of Gaza has left over 10,000 Gazans dead, according to the Gazan health ministry.

item.title: Israel Raises Alarms by Suggesting ‘Indefinite’ Role in Gaza
item.description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken quickly pushed back, but what exactly comes next is far from clear.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger and Isabel Kershner
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: An Israeli tank operating near the border with Gaza in Israel this month.

item.title: Israel and Hamas Nearly Struck a Deal to Free Up to 50 Hostages
item.description: Indirect talks mediated by Qatar snagged after Israel’s ground invasion of Gaza on Oct. 27. They have resumed, but hopes for a quick release have faded.
item.dc:creator: Maria Abi-Habib and Matthew Rosenberg
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: People attend a rally on Monday in Jerusalem supporting families of the captives held by Hamas.

item.title: A Gaza ‘Cease-Fire’ or a ‘Pause’? Even World Leaders Are Confused.
item.description: Experts say neither term is defined under international law.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:credit: Yousef Masoud for The New York Times
item.media:description: A destroyed area after an Israeli airstrike on Khan Younis, in southern Gaza.

item.title: As Israel Pushes Deeper Into Northern Gaza, Thousands Trek South
item.description: The United Nations estimates that 15,000 people used the only route out of the northern part of the enclave on Tuesday, three times the number that passed the day before.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times

item.title: Reading List: Scams and Scammers
item.description: Sam Bankman-Fried’s conviction reminds us of the real talent behind the schemes — knowing what people yearn for.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:description: Sam Bankman-Fried, who founded the FTX cryptocurrency exchange, leaving court in July.

item.title: Sunak Clashes With Police Chief Over Planned Pro-Palestinian March
item.description: A demonstration in London that will coincide with remembrance events has divided the prime minister and the country’s most senior police officer.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: A Pro-Palestinian protest in London last Saturday. Demonstrators called for a cease-fire in the Hamas-Israel conflict.

item.title: 2023 Virtually Certain to Be the Hottest Year on Record, Scientists Say
item.description: Analyzing data from October, European climate scientists found another record-breaking month for temperatures around the world.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Employees of the City Council in São Paulo, Brazil, distributed bottled water during a heat wave in September.

item.title: France Suspects Foreign Influence in Star of David Graffiti
item.description: After more than 200 blue stars were stenciled on buildings in and around Paris, prosecutors say they are investigating whether a foreign intermediary paid a couple to spray paint them.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: More than 60 blue stars were found in the 14th arrondissement of Paris on the morning of Oct. 31, while others have appeared in two suburbs of the capital.

item.title: Senate Democrats Challenge Biden on Israel, Seeking Assurances About Aid
item.description: A majority of the Democratic caucus signed a letter asking President Biden to ensure that Israel has a viable plan for defeating Hamas and will use U.S. military assistance in keeping with international law.
item.dc:creator: Karoun Demirjian
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senate Democrats asked for details on how the Biden administration would ensure that Israel was properly mitigating civilian casualties in Gaza.

item.title: Lucky Find at Auction Identifies Man on Cover of ‘Led Zeppelin IV’
item.description: It’s not a painting. It’s a picture of a Victorian artisan taken in the English countryside in 1892.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses

item.title: Ukraine Gets an Encouraging Sign in Its Bid to Join the E.U.
item.description: The European Union’s executive arm recommended beginning membership talks with Ukraine on condition of some further changes in Kyiv.
item.dc:creator: Monika Pronczuk
item.media:description: Ursula von der Leyen, the head of the European Commission, said on Wednesday that Ukrainians were “deeply reforming their country” even as they fought to defend it.

item.title: As Pandas Leave National Zoo, Is Panda Diplomacy Over?
item.description: The giant pandas have left Washington. Some fans find it unbearable.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong and Erin Schaff
item.media:description: The Smithsonian’s National Zoo in the heart of Washington has panda posters, panda mugs, panda pajamas, panda puzzles and even panda ice cream.

item.title: Wage Hike Fails to Appease Protesting Garment Workers in Bangladesh
item.description: Unions in Bangladesh say a proposed wage increase falls short after a weekend of violent protests.
item.dc:creator: Saif Hasnat
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Workers at a garment factory on the outskirts of Dhaka, Bangladesh, in July.

item.title: Drought in Syria, Iran and Iraq Made ‘Extreme’ by Global Warming, Attribution Study Says
item.description: Syria, Iraq and Iran were parched by high temperatures that would have been “virtually impossible” without the effects of global warming, scientists said.
item.dc:creator: Manuela Andreoni
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mashoofs, a type of boat used by residents of Mesopotamia’s marshes, parked at the edge of a shrinking waterway in Chibayish, Iraq, in 2022.

item.title: Behind Hamas’s Bloody Gambit to Create a ‘Permanent’ State of War
item.description: Hamas leaders say they waged their Oct. 7 attack on Israel because they believed the Palestinian cause was slipping away, and that only violence could revive it.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Maria Abi-Habib
item.media:credit: Yousef Masoud for The New York Times
item.media:description: Palestinians surveying the damage caused by Israeli airstrikes in Khan Younis, in the southern Gaza Strip, last month.

item.title: Éric Dupond-Moretti, France’s Justice Minister, Goes on Trial
item.description: The case is the first time a sitting government minister has gone before a court, and it is part of the system he continues to oversee.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter
item.media:description: Justice Minister Éric Dupond-Moretti at the Élysée Palace in July. Mr. Dupond-Moretti faces a 10-day trial.

item.title: Underwater Volcano Forms New Island in Japan
item.description: An ongoing eruption from the volcano has created a small land mass less than a mile off Iwo Jima island. It’s a great case study of how volcanoes work.
item.dc:creator: Hisako Ueno and Mike Ives
item.media:description: Photos showing the eruption from an underwater volcano in Japan last weekend.

item.title: How One Small Statistic Became a Story That Spanned a Continent
item.description: Our chief Africa reporter was wary of journalism that made broad predictions about the continent, but a statistic made clear that staggering change was approaching.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.media:credit: Hannah Reyes Morales for The New York Times
item.media:description: With a median age of 19, Africa is the continent with the world’s youngest population. Senegal’s youth can be felt at Yoff Beach in Dakar, the capital.

item.title: Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Calls for a cease-fire in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: A rally in Amman, Jordan, to show support for Palestinians in Gaza.

item.title: A New Answer for Migrants in Central America: Bus Them North
item.description: Costa Rica and Panama are busing people through their countries to ease the concentration of people along their borders, which Biden officials fear will encourage more people to travel to the U.S. border.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs, David Bolaños and Daniele Volpe
item.media:credit: Daniele Volpe for The New York Times
item.media:description: Migrants, mostly Venezuelans, waiting to get access to the bus that will take them to the border with Nicaragua last month in Paso Canoa, Costa Rica.

item.title: Germans Recoil at Push to Rename ‘Anne Frank’ Day Care
item.description: The proposed change, reportedly at the behest of parents and employees who found her story difficult to explain to children, comes amid acute concern about rising antisemitism in Germany.
item.dc:creator: Graham Bowley
item.media:description: Anne Frank, a young Jewish girl who became one of the most well-known victims of the Holocaust, pictured in 1941. She died at the Bergen-Belsen concentration camp toward the end of World War II.

item.title: As Ukraine Seeks Troops, Women Prepare for the Call
item.description: With so much in the war against Russia hinging on refilling the ranks of soldiers, efforts are underway to draw more Ukrainian women into the army.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Maria Varenikova
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Women participating in a course in firearms and urban combat in a forest near Ukraine’s capital, Kyiv, last month.

item.title: Fossil Fuel Use Increasing, Not Decreasing, as Key Target Looms
item.description: The world remains on track to produce far more oil, gas and coal than would be consistent with relatively safe levels of heating, a new report found.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: A gas processing plant in Seminole, Texas. Emissions from burning coal, oil and gas are the main drivers of global warming,
